title: Lesson 6: Eukaryotic Plant Cells
moduleTitle: Cells as the Basis of Life
description: Understanding the unique structures of plant cells including chloroplasts, central vacuole, and cell wall. Students learn to distinguish plant and animal cells and calculate water potential.
learningIntentions: Students can identify structures unique to plant cells (chloroplasts, central vacuole, cell wall, plasmodesmata).
Students can distinguish between animal and plant cells using structural criteria.
Students can calculate water potential using ψ = ψs + ψp and predict water movement.

engagementHook.title: The Green Factory
engagementHook.content: Show a time-lapse of a seedling growing toward light. 'This tiny plant can make its own food from sunlight, water, and air. Inside each of its cells are structures no animal has—green chloroplasts that capture sunlight, a massive water-filled vacuole that keeps it upright, and a rigid wall that lets it grow tall without bones. How do these structures let plants thrive while animals wander?'

keyConcepts.definition: Double-membrane organelles containing thylakoids (stacked into grana) and stroma. Site of photosynthesis. Contain chlorophyll (green pigment), own DNA, and 70S ribosomes (endosymbiotic origin).
Large, membrane-bound sac (tonoplast membrane) containing cell sap. Maintains turgor pressure against cell wall, stores water, ions, and pigments. Can occupy 30-80% of cell volume.
Rigid outer layer composed of cellulose microfibrils embedded in matrix. Provides structural support, protection, and prevents osmotic lysis. Outside the plasma membrane.
Channels through cell walls connecting adjacent plant cells, allowing transport and communication between cells.
Colourless plastids that store starch. Found in roots and seeds.
Measure of potential energy of water, measured in MPa or kPa. ψ = ψs (solute potential) + ψp (pressure potential). Water moves from high ψ (less negative) to low ψ (more negative).

misconceptions.misconception: Plant cells have all the same organelles as animal cells plus extras
misconceptions.correction: Plant cells LACK centrioles (used in animal cell division). Emphasise this difference.

misconceptions.misconception: The vacuole is just empty space
misconceptions.correction: It's filled with cell sap (water, ions, sugars, pigments) and is metabolically active.
Cell walls are non-living secretions outside the plasma membrane.

contentSections.content: Double outer membrane, internal thylakoids (flattened sacs) stacked into grana, stroma (fluid matrix), DNA and ribosomes shown.
contentSections.example: Spinach leaves - each mesophyll cell contains 40-50 chloroplasts.

contentSections.title: The Central Vacuole
contentSections.content: The tonoplast (vacuole membrane) encloses cell sap - a solution of water, ions, sugars, pigments (anthocyanins), and waste products. When full, it presses the cytoplasm against the cell wall creating turgor pressure (0.1-1 MPa). This rigid pressure supports the plant. When water is scarce, the vacuole shrinks, turgor drops, and the plant wilts.
contentSections.example: Celery becomes limp when dehydrated (loss of turgor) but crisp when hydrated.
contentSections.checkForUnderstanding: What happens to a plant cell if the central vacuole loses water? (Plasmolysis - cell membrane pulls away from wall)

contentSections.title: Animal vs Plant Cells
contentSections.note: Both have: nucleus, mitochondria, ribosomes, ER, Golgi, plasma membrane

activities.title: Water Potential Calculation
activities.description: Calculate water potential and predict water movement.
activities.question: A plant cell has solute potential (ψs) of -0.5 MPa and pressure potential (ψp) of 0.3 MPa. Calculate its water potential (ψ).
activities.hint: Add the two potentials together. Remember: water moves from high ψ to low ψ.

multipleChoice.question: Which structure is found in plant cells but NOT in animal cells?
multipleChoice.rationale: Chloroplasts are unique to plant cells (and some algae). Mitochondria, nucleus, and ribosomes are found in both.

multipleChoice.question: A plant cell is placed in pure water. Which statement is correct?
options: Water will move out of the cell
The cell will burst due to osmotic lysis
Water will enter the cell, creating turgor pressure
No net water movement will occur
multipleChoice.correctAnswer: Water will enter the cell, creating turgor pressure
multipleChoice.rationale: Pure water (0 MPa) has higher water potential than cell contents. Water enters, pressing membrane against cell wall (turgor). Cell wall prevents bursting.

multipleChoice.question: The cell walls of plants are composed of:
multipleChoice.rationale: Plant cell walls contain cellulose. Bacteria = peptidoglycan, Fungi = chitin, Animals store glycogen (not in walls).

shortAnswer.question: Explain the role of the large central vacuole in maintaining turgor pressure. [3 marks]
markingCriteria: 1 mark: Vacuole contains cell sap (water, ions) pressing against cell wall
1 mark: This creates turgor pressure (hydrostatic pressure)
1 mark: Turgor pressure provides structural support/rigidity to the plant (prevents wilting)
shortAnswer.commonError: Not mentioning the role of the cell wall in resisting expansion.

shortAnswer.question: Describe two pieces of evidence that suggest chloroplasts evolved from free-living prokaryotes. [2 marks]
markingCriteria: 1 mark: Double membrane (suggests engulfing by host cell)
1 mark: Own circular DNA (similar to bacteria) OR 70S ribosomes (prokaryotic size) OR reproduce by binary fission
shortAnswer.commonError: Mentioning 'has DNA' without specifying circular; confusing with mitochondria features.

definitions: Plant cells have chloroplasts for photosynthesis (double membrane, own DNA, thylakoids).
Large central vacuole maintains turgor pressure against cell wall.
Cell walls provide structural support (cellulose microfibrils).
Plasmodesmata allow intercellular communication through cell walls.
Water potential (ψ) = ψs + ψp; water moves from high to low ψ.
keyPoints: Chloroplasts: thylakoids contain chlorophyll; stroma contains enzymes
Central vacuole: 30-80% of cell volume; maintains turgor pressure
Cellulose cell wall: outside plasma membrane; prevents osmotic lysis
Plant cells lack centrioles (present in animal cells)
Pure water ψ = 0 MPa; adding solutes makes ψ negative
diagrams: Labelled plant cell showing chloroplasts, vacuole, cell wall
Chloroplast structure with thylakoids and grana

shortAnswer: The large central vacuole contains cell sap (a solution of water, ions, and sugars) which presses the cytoplasm against the cell wall. This creates turgor pressure (hydrostatic pressure) that provides structural support and rigidity to the plant. When the vacuole is full, the plant stands upright; when water is lost, turgor pressure drops and the plant wilts.

Evidence that chloroplasts evolved from free-living prokaryotes includes: (1) They have a double membrane, which suggests they were engulfed by an ancestral eukaryotic cell. (2) They contain their own circular DNA, similar to bacteria, rather than linear DNA like the nucleus. (3) They contain 70S ribosomes, which are the same size as prokaryotic ribosomes. (4) They reproduce by binary fission, like bacteria.
